ranked_diseases.explanation: Strong match with cardiac defects (PDA, coarctation), facial dysmorphism (hypertelorism, depressed nasal bridge, prominent forehead), short neck, pectus carinatum, cryptorchidism, and developmental delays. PTPN11 mutation-associated form.
Similar phenotypic profile to NS1 with cardiac anomalies, facial features, and developmental delays. Associated with KRAS mutations, may have slightly different cardiac manifestations.
KRAS-related variant presenting with typical Noonan features including cardiac defects, facial dysmorphism, and developmental delays, though specific cardiac lesions may vary.

Shares several features including short neck, coarctation of aorta, hypertelorism, and hypothyroidism. However, patient is male (cryptorchidism present), making this less likely but mosaic forms possible.
SOS1-associated Noonan syndrome with characteristic facial features, cardiac defects, and developmental delays. May have higher frequency of ectodermal abnormalities.
RASopathy with overlapping features including cardiac defects, facial dysmorphism, developmental delays, and ectodermal abnormalities. BRAF-associated form.
RIT1-associated variant with typical Noonan features including cardiac anomalies, facial dysmorphism, and developmental delays.
PTPN11-related disorder with cardiac defects and facial features similar to Noonan syndrome, though typically includes lentigines which are not mentioned in this case.
RASopathy with cardiac defects, facial dysmorphism, and developmental delays. HRAS mutations typically cause more severe phenotype with increased tumor risk.
Features blepharophimosis, cardiac defects, developmental delays, and skeletal abnormalities. KMT2D-associated form, though typical facial gestalt differs from presented features.
